comment.author: 87724873@N00
comment._content: I wonder whether she could be this Mary Malone: workinglives.econ.usyd.edu.au/malone.html

comment.author: 8368002@N03
comment._content: Or perhaps she's this woman, listed as a passenger on the White Star Liner Adriatic in 1908: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C01EEDC153EE233A...

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Far more likely to be Mary S. Malone, Delaware's woman factory inspector, and a crusader against child labor, who testified to Congress in 1914: books.google.com/books?id=fwwXAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA42&am...

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content: This is definitely Mary S. Malone, Delaware factory inspector. There are 3 photos of her with other factory inspectors in the Library of Congress National Child Labor Committee collection. Here's one of them www.loc.gov/pictures/item/ncl2004002787/PP/

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: The same photo of her in The Caucasian., July 06, 1913, Image 2, column 1. She was appointed the ten hour law inspector in Delaware.
